description.summary: The most famous UFO incident in history. In July 1947, debris was recovered from a ranch near Roswell, New Mexico. Initially reported as a 'flying disc' by the Army, the story was quickly retracted as a weather balloon. Decades later, witnesses came forward claiming alien bodies and government cover-up.
description.full: The Roswell Incident is the most famous and controversial UFO event in history. On July 8, 1947, the Roswell Army Air Field issued a press release stating they had recovered a 'flying disc' from a ranch near Roswell, New Mexico. Within hours, the story was retracted and explained as a weather balloon. The incident was largely forgotten until the late 1970s when researchers began interviewing witnesses who claimed to have seen alien bodies and exotic debris. The U.S. government later explained the debris as part of Project Mogul, a classified balloon program. Despite official explanations, the Roswell Incident remains the foundation of modern UFO culture and conspiracy theories about government cover-ups of extraterrestrial contact.

debris_descriptions.description: Thin metal-like material that returned to original shape when crumpled
Small structural beams with hieroglyphic-like markings
Extremely thin, lightweight, could not be cut or burned
Thin fibers described as unlike anything known

alleged_bodies.notes: Body claims emerged 30+ years after event

timeline.description: Mac Brazel discovers unusual debris scattered across Foster Ranch
Brazel reports debris to Sheriff George Wilcox in Roswell
RAAF issues press release: 'RAAF Captures Flying Saucer on Ranch in Roswell Region'
General Ramey holds press conference, displays weather balloon debris
Mac Brazel allegedly held at RAAF for several days
Stanton Friedman interviews Jesse Marcel, reigniting interest
U.S. Air Force releases report identifying debris as Project Mogul balloon
USAF attributes alien body claims to crash test dummies from 1950s tests
